content: Here is an article from Global Research that is quite interesting. I do not agree with all points, but I do agree with about 95% of what is contained herein. The rise in the equities market is indeed a stock market bubble induced by the Federal Reserve. This is easily seen when comparing the values of stocks over the past rally to the conditions of the economy. Also, the market is not the root of the problem, so it doesn't even reflect the economy as a whole. The root of the problem was that the Federal Reserve lowered the discount window to 1% six years ago, which allowed the banks to borrow the almost free money and lend it to whoever the hell they wanted to. Thus creating the housing bubble. When that burst, it created a downward spiral that caused a crash in housing, a failed banking system, failing industries and skyrocketing unemployment. Notice, the equities market itself has nothing to do with any of this. Today, the rise in the market is the result of speculators taking advantage of the Fed's capital injections before those capital injections fail. In other words, the money hungries are making their money while they can. Wells Fargo was a story of optimism over the past few weeks. But, what is really going on here. As many of you know, I was quick to show the problems associated with the FASB easing mark-to-market rules. Because, Wells Fargos profits are nothing more than their overvaluing of their worthless mortgage-backed assets, merger accounting and mortgage default moratoriums. Their profits are not a reflection of trends in the economy. A good indicator of this is the fact that their stock has been downgraded to "underperform". Deflation is still strong as ever. Fuel, food wholesale and housing prices are still falling. Unemployment is still seeing record lows as we lose 650,000 jobs a month. Both the manufacturing and Industrial sectors are at record lows. These are the true indicators of the state of the economy, not the stock market. This is a point that I have some reservations about, but that is only because I opposed the stimulus in the first place. But, it is quite interesting. Our size of our economy is about $14 trillion. The stimulus was only $787 billion. With unemployment continuing to rise, the manufacturing and industrial sectors continuing to fall, how can we expect the stimulus to have any effect on an economy where consumer spending accounts for 72% of total GDP? We can't. The only indicator of any optimism in our economy coming back is that the stock market has been rallying. And, as can be easily seen, that is not a real indicator at all. Plus, it is even scarier when you find out that the Federal Reserve is using cheap money to boost the equities market and to induce borrowing when that is exactly what got us into this mess in the first place. Here is the article: ---http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=13236

content: And here I thought the stimulus (aka the infrastructure bailout) was supposed to help get thigns moving again. Caterpillar was supposed to be one of the main benefitiaries. Apparently, its not happening fast enough or big enough.. quote: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and mining equipment, on Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $112 million, hurt by sharp sales declines across the globe and a big charge for recent layoffs. The loss was Caterpillar's first since 1992 and highlighted the depth and breadth of a global downturn that forced double-digit sales drops in most of Caterpillar's product lines. Caterpillar's vast geographic reach and array of products -- including machines used to build roads and bridges, engines that power oceangoing freighters and mining trucks that haul materials like iron ore -- make it a bellwether of the world economy. The company also said the economic climate has deteriorated, despite government stimulus plans and better-than-expected commodity prices. With lending still tight and the U.S. recession tougher than expected in the first quarter, Caterpillar lowered its outlook. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Caterpillar-posts-loss-hurt-apf-14985051.html

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: You want a crystal ball on the economy watch companies like these: quote: ATLANTA (AP) -- UPS Inc.'s first-quarter profit plunged as fewer people sent packages and used premium services like next-day air amid the global financial crisis. The world's largest shipping carrier also gave a disappointing second-quarter outlook on Thursday, and disclosed it shed 10,000 domestic jobs during the first three months of the year. UPS earnings in the January-March period fell more than 55 percent to $401 million as revenue dropped more than 13 percent, compared to profit of $906 million a year ago. The results missed Wall Street expectations, and UPS provided an outlook for second-quarter earnings that was below analysts expectations. UPS shares fell. [...] Rival FedEx Corp. also has been facing financial headwinds from the weak economy. In March, the Memphis, Tenn.-based company said it would cut more jobs and trim wages again, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on sliding revenue. Earlier this month, FedEx said it would permanently remove 14 jets from service as part of an overall plan to reduce capacity. Economists and analysts consider FedEx and UPS to be bellwethers of the global economy, since they deal with such basic indicators of company health as orders and product shipments. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/UPS-1Q-profit-plunges-more-apf-15012558.html This after competitor DHL closed down opperations in North America.

content: But, but, but the banks are all showing profits.. quote: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians. Another day, another attempt by a Wall Street bank to pull a bunny out of the hat, showing off an earnings report that it hopes will elicit oohs and aahs from the market. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and, on Monday, Bank of America all tried to wow their audiences with what appeared to be — presto! — better-than-expected numbers. But in each case, investors spotted the attempts at sleight of hand, and didn’t buy it for a second. With Goldman Sachs, the disappearing month of December didn’t quite disappear (it changed its reporting calendar, effectively erasing the impact of a $1.5 billion loss that month); JPMorgan Chase reported a dazzling profit partly because the price of its bonds dropped (theoretically, they could retire them and buy them back at a cheaper price; that’s sort of like saying you’re richer because the value of your home has dropped); Citigroup pulled the same trick. Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3

content: Here is an article from Global Research that is quite interesting. I do not agree with all points, but I do agree with about 95% of what is contained herein. The rise in the equities market is indeed a stock market bubble induced by the Federal Reserve. This is easily seen when comparing the values of stocks over the past rally to the conditions of the economy. Also, the market is not the root of the problem, so it doesn't even reflect the economy as a whole. The root of the problem was that the Federal Reserve lowered the discount window to 1% six years ago, which allowed the banks to borrow the almost free money and lend it to whoever the hell they wanted to. Thus creating the housing bubble. When that burst, it created a downward spiral that caused a crash in housing, a failed banking system, failing industries and skyrocketing unemployment. Notice, the equities market itself has nothing to do with any of this. Today, the rise in the market is the result of speculators taking advantage of the Fed's capital injections before those capital injections fail. In other words, the money hungries are making their money while they can. Wells Fargo was a story of optimism over the past few weeks. But, what is really going on here. As many of you know, I was quick to show the problems associated with the FASB easing mark-to-market rules. Because, Wells Fargos profits are nothing more than their overvaluing of their worthless mortgage-backed assets, merger accounting and mortgage default moratoriums. Their profits are not a reflection of trends in the economy. A good indicator of this is the fact that their stock has been downgraded to "underperform". Deflation is still strong as ever. Fuel, food wholesale and housing prices are still falling. Unemployment is still seeing record lows as we lose 650,000 jobs a month. Both the manufacturing and Industrial sectors are at record lows. These are the true indicators of the state of the economy, not the stock market. This is a point that I have some reservations about, but that is only because I opposed the stimulus in the first place. But, it is quite interesting. Our size of our economy is about $14 trillion. The stimulus was only $787 billion. With unemployment continuing to rise, the manufacturing and industrial sectors continuing to fall, how can we expect the stimulus to have any effect on an economy where consumer spending accounts for 72% of total GDP? We can't. The only indicator of any optimism in our economy coming back is that the stock market has been rallying. And, as can be easily seen, that is not a real indicator at all. Plus, it is even scarier when you find out that the Federal Reserve is using cheap money to boost the equities market and to induce borrowing when that is exactly what got us into this mess in the first place. Here is the article: ---http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=13236

Basically, I read and/or watch/listen to anything and everything other than the MSM. And, I have found them to be far more accurate in their reporting. This I found out when my ship was involved in news-making events or I knew others who were involved in news-making events (SEALs, EOD, FBI, DHS, US Marine Corps, US Army, CIA, etc). Often, the news-making things that my friends and I were involved in were completely butchered in most American news sources. But, they were reported with crystal clarity in alternative and foreign news sources. That was more than enough for me to completely shun all American MSM outlets.

content: Since we dont have crystal balls and are limited to the biased media,and cant rely on past history in this case, all we can do is unfortunately watch and see on a daily basis. The worst thing we can do is take a positive and try to make it a negative. It is what it is. The fact the market is improving is an indicator money is changing hands and thats a positive. The unemployment is the last thing that will improve in sequence and may get worse as they restructure. The work is out there just waiting for the funding. In NY alone there are projects on the drawing boards that will provide for full employement plus some. Right now everything is on hold and will proceed in the proper order. It must be remembered that something either grows or it dies. No such thing as limbo and NYC is nowhere close to dieing as is the USA.

content: And here I thought the stimulus (aka the infrastructure bailout) was supposed to help get thigns moving again. Caterpillar was supposed to be one of the main benefitiaries. Apparently, its not happening fast enough or big enough.. quote: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and mining equipment, on Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $112 million, hurt by sharp sales declines across the globe and a big charge for recent layoffs. The loss was Caterpillar's first since 1992 and highlighted the depth and breadth of a global downturn that forced double-digit sales drops in most of Caterpillar's product lines. Caterpillar's vast geographic reach and array of products -- including machines used to build roads and bridges, engines that power oceangoing freighters and mining trucks that haul materials like iron ore -- make it a bellwether of the world economy. The company also said the economic climate has deteriorated, despite government stimulus plans and better-than-expected commodity prices. With lending still tight and the U.S. recession tougher than expected in the first quarter, Caterpillar lowered its outlook. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Caterpillar-posts-loss-hurt-apf-14985051.html

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: You want a crystal ball on the economy watch companies like these: quote: ATLANTA (AP) -- UPS Inc.'s first-quarter profit plunged as fewer people sent packages and used premium services like next-day air amid the global financial crisis. The world's largest shipping carrier also gave a disappointing second-quarter outlook on Thursday, and disclosed it shed 10,000 domestic jobs during the first three months of the year. UPS earnings in the January-March period fell more than 55 percent to $401 million as revenue dropped more than 13 percent, compared to profit of $906 million a year ago. The results missed Wall Street expectations, and UPS provided an outlook for second-quarter earnings that was below analysts expectations. UPS shares fell. [...] Rival FedEx Corp. also has been facing financial headwinds from the weak economy. In March, the Memphis, Tenn.-based company said it would cut more jobs and trim wages again, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on sliding revenue. Earlier this month, FedEx said it would permanently remove 14 jets from service as part of an overall plan to reduce capacity. Economists and analysts consider FedEx and UPS to be bellwethers of the global economy, since they deal with such basic indicators of company health as orders and product shipments. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/UPS-1Q-profit-plunges-more-apf-15012558.html This after competitor DHL closed down opperations in North America.

content: But, but, but the banks are all showing profits.. quote: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians. Another day, another attempt by a Wall Street bank to pull a bunny out of the hat, showing off an earnings report that it hopes will elicit oohs and aahs from the market. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and, on Monday, Bank of America all tried to wow their audiences with what appeared to be — presto! — better-than-expected numbers. But in each case, investors spotted the attempts at sleight of hand, and didn’t buy it for a second. With Goldman Sachs, the disappearing month of December didn’t quite disappear (it changed its reporting calendar, effectively erasing the impact of a $1.5 billion loss that month); JPMorgan Chase reported a dazzling profit partly because the price of its bonds dropped (theoretically, they could retire them and buy them back at a cheaper price; that’s sort of like saying you’re richer because the value of your home has dropped); Citigroup pulled the same trick. Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3

content: Here is an article from Global Research that is quite interesting. I do not agree with all points, but I do agree with about 95% of what is contained herein. The rise in the equities market is indeed a stock market bubble induced by the Federal Reserve. This is easily seen when comparing the values of stocks over the past rally to the conditions of the economy. Also, the market is not the root of the problem, so it doesn't even reflect the economy as a whole. The root of the problem was that the Federal Reserve lowered the discount window to 1% six years ago, which allowed the banks to borrow the almost free money and lend it to whoever the hell they wanted to. Thus creating the housing bubble. When that burst, it created a downward spiral that caused a crash in housing, a failed banking system, failing industries and skyrocketing unemployment. Notice, the equities market itself has nothing to do with any of this. Today, the rise in the market is the result of speculators taking advantage of the Fed's capital injections before those capital injections fail. In other words, the money hungries are making their money while they can. Wells Fargo was a story of optimism over the past few weeks. But, what is really going on here. As many of you know, I was quick to show the problems associated with the FASB easing mark-to-market rules. Because, Wells Fargos profits are nothing more than their overvaluing of their worthless mortgage-backed assets, merger accounting and mortgage default moratoriums. Their profits are not a reflection of trends in the economy. A good indicator of this is the fact that their stock has been downgraded to "underperform". Deflation is still strong as ever. Fuel, food wholesale and housing prices are still falling. Unemployment is still seeing record lows as we lose 650,000 jobs a month. Both the manufacturing and Industrial sectors are at record lows. These are the true indicators of the state of the economy, not the stock market. This is a point that I have some reservations about, but that is only because I opposed the stimulus in the first place. But, it is quite interesting. Our size of our economy is about $14 trillion. The stimulus was only $787 billion. With unemployment continuing to rise, the manufacturing and industrial sectors continuing to fall, how can we expect the stimulus to have any effect on an economy where consumer spending accounts for 72% of total GDP? We can't. The only indicator of any optimism in our economy coming back is that the stock market has been rallying. And, as can be easily seen, that is not a real indicator at all. Plus, it is even scarier when you find out that the Federal Reserve is using cheap money to boost the equities market and to induce borrowing when that is exactly what got us into this mess in the first place. Here is the article: ---http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=13236

content: I too keep up with the CBC even though it isn't available where I live. Their website is fantastic, though. I also read the Canadian National Post, Al Jazeera English, Aftenposten, Alnadwah, The Guardian, The Moscow Times, Haaretz, The Jerusalem Post, The Moscow Times, Pravda, Milliyet, Creaders, Sydney Morning Herald, Japan Times, La Stampa, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Infowars, Axis of Logic, Corporate Watch, Alternet, Disinformation, Independent Media Center, Information Clearing House, The Economist, Opensecrets, RINF, Truthout and Z Net. Basically, I read and/or watch/listen to anything and everything other than the MSM. And, I have found them to be far more accurate in their reporting. This I found out when my ship was involved in news-making events or I knew others who were involved in news-making events (SEALs, EOD, FBI, DHS, US Marine Corps, US Army, CIA, etc). Often, the news-making things that my friends and I were involved in were completely butchered in most American news sources. But, they were reported with crystal clarity in alternative and foreign news sources. That was more than enough for me to completely shun all American MSM outlets.

content: Since we dont have crystal balls and are limited to the biased media,and cant rely on past history in this case, all we can do is unfortunately watch and see on a daily basis. The worst thing we can do is take a positive and try to make it a negative. It is what it is. The fact the market is improving is an indicator money is changing hands and thats a positive. The unemployment is the last thing that will improve in sequence and may get worse as they restructure. The work is out there just waiting for the funding. In NY alone there are projects on the drawing boards that will provide for full employement plus some. Right now everything is on hold and will proceed in the proper order. It must be remembered that something either grows or it dies. No such thing as limbo and NYC is nowhere close to dieing as is the USA.

content: And here I thought the stimulus (aka the infrastructure bailout) was supposed to help get thigns moving again. Caterpillar was supposed to be one of the main benefitiaries. Apparently, its not happening fast enough or big enough.. quote: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and mining equipment, on Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $112 million, hurt by sharp sales declines across the globe and a big charge for recent layoffs. The loss was Caterpillar's first since 1992 and highlighted the depth and breadth of a global downturn that forced double-digit sales drops in most of Caterpillar's product lines. Caterpillar's vast geographic reach and array of products -- including machines used to build roads and bridges, engines that power oceangoing freighters and mining trucks that haul materials like iron ore -- make it a bellwether of the world economy. The company also said the economic climate has deteriorated, despite government stimulus plans and better-than-expected commodity prices. With lending still tight and the U.S. recession tougher than expected in the first quarter, Caterpillar lowered its outlook. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Caterpillar-posts-loss-hurt-apf-14985051.html

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: You want a crystal ball on the economy watch companies like these: quote: ATLANTA (AP) -- UPS Inc.'s first-quarter profit plunged as fewer people sent packages and used premium services like next-day air amid the global financial crisis. The world's largest shipping carrier also gave a disappointing second-quarter outlook on Thursday, and disclosed it shed 10,000 domestic jobs during the first three months of the year. UPS earnings in the January-March period fell more than 55 percent to $401 million as revenue dropped more than 13 percent, compared to profit of $906 million a year ago. The results missed Wall Street expectations, and UPS provided an outlook for second-quarter earnings that was below analysts expectations. UPS shares fell. [...] Rival FedEx Corp. also has been facing financial headwinds from the weak economy. In March, the Memphis, Tenn.-based company said it would cut more jobs and trim wages again, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on sliding revenue. Earlier this month, FedEx said it would permanently remove 14 jets from service as part of an overall plan to reduce capacity. Economists and analysts consider FedEx and UPS to be bellwethers of the global economy, since they deal with such basic indicators of company health as orders and product shipments. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/UPS-1Q-profit-plunges-more-apf-15012558.html This after competitor DHL closed down opperations in North America.

content: But, but, but the banks are all showing profits.. quote: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians. Another day, another attempt by a Wall Street bank to pull a bunny out of the hat, showing off an earnings report that it hopes will elicit oohs and aahs from the market. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and, on Monday, Bank of America all tried to wow their audiences with what appeared to be — presto! — better-than-expected numbers. But in each case, investors spotted the attempts at sleight of hand, and didn’t buy it for a second. With Goldman Sachs, the disappearing month of December didn’t quite disappear (it changed its reporting calendar, effectively erasing the impact of a $1.5 billion loss that month); JPMorgan Chase reported a dazzling profit partly because the price of its bonds dropped (theoretically, they could retire them and buy them back at a cheaper price; that’s sort of like saying you’re richer because the value of your home has dropped); Citigroup pulled the same trick. Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3

Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3

content: Here is an article from Global Research that is quite interesting. I do not agree with all points, but I do agree with about 95% of what is contained herein. The rise in the equities market is indeed a stock market bubble induced by the Federal Reserve. This is easily seen when comparing the values of stocks over the past rally to the conditions of the economy. Also, the market is not the root of the problem, so it doesn't even reflect the economy as a whole. The root of the problem was that the Federal Reserve lowered the discount window to 1% six years ago, which allowed the banks to borrow the almost free money and lend it to whoever the hell they wanted to. Thus creating the housing bubble. When that burst, it created a downward spiral that caused a crash in housing, a failed banking system, failing industries and skyrocketing unemployment. Notice, the equities market itself has nothing to do with any of this. Today, the rise in the market is the result of speculators taking advantage of the Fed's capital injections before those capital injections fail. In other words, the money hungries are making their money while they can. Wells Fargo was a story of optimism over the past few weeks. But, what is really going on here. As many of you know, I was quick to show the problems associated with the FASB easing mark-to-market rules. Because, Wells Fargos profits are nothing more than their overvaluing of their worthless mortgage-backed assets, merger accounting and mortgage default moratoriums. Their profits are not a reflection of trends in the economy. A good indicator of this is the fact that their stock has been downgraded to "underperform". Deflation is still strong as ever. Fuel, food wholesale and housing prices are still falling. Unemployment is still seeing record lows as we lose 650,000 jobs a month. Both the manufacturing and Industrial sectors are at record lows. These are the true indicators of the state of the economy, not the stock market. This is a point that I have some reservations about, but that is only because I opposed the stimulus in the first place. But, it is quite interesting. Our size of our economy is about $14 trillion. The stimulus was only $787 billion. With unemployment continuing to rise, the manufacturing and industrial sectors continuing to fall, how can we expect the stimulus to have any effect on an economy where consumer spending accounts for 72% of total GDP? We can't. The only indicator of any optimism in our economy coming back is that the stock market has been rallying. And, as can be easily seen, that is not a real indicator at all. Plus, it is even scarier when you find out that the Federal Reserve is using cheap money to boost the equities market and to induce borrowing when that is exactly what got us into this mess in the first place. Here is the article: ---http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=13236

content: And here I thought the stimulus (aka the infrastructure bailout) was supposed to help get thigns moving again. Caterpillar was supposed to be one of the main benefitiaries. Apparently, its not happening fast enough or big enough.. quote: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and mining equipment, on Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $112 million, hurt by sharp sales declines across the globe and a big charge for recent layoffs. The loss was Caterpillar's first since 1992 and highlighted the depth and breadth of a global downturn that forced double-digit sales drops in most of Caterpillar's product lines. Caterpillar's vast geographic reach and array of products -- including machines used to build roads and bridges, engines that power oceangoing freighters and mining trucks that haul materials like iron ore -- make it a bellwether of the world economy. The company also said the economic climate has deteriorated, despite government stimulus plans and better-than-expected commodity prices. With lending still tight and the U.S. recession tougher than expected in the first quarter, Caterpillar lowered its outlook. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Caterpillar-posts-loss-hurt-apf-14985051.html

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: You want a crystal ball on the economy watch companies like these: quote: ATLANTA (AP) -- UPS Inc.'s first-quarter profit plunged as fewer people sent packages and used premium services like next-day air amid the global financial crisis. The world's largest shipping carrier also gave a disappointing second-quarter outlook on Thursday, and disclosed it shed 10,000 domestic jobs during the first three months of the year. UPS earnings in the January-March period fell more than 55 percent to $401 million as revenue dropped more than 13 percent, compared to profit of $906 million a year ago. The results missed Wall Street expectations, and UPS provided an outlook for second-quarter earnings that was below analysts expectations. UPS shares fell. [...] Rival FedEx Corp. also has been facing financial headwinds from the weak economy. In March, the Memphis, Tenn.-based company said it would cut more jobs and trim wages again, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on sliding revenue. Earlier this month, FedEx said it would permanently remove 14 jets from service as part of an overall plan to reduce capacity. Economists and analysts consider FedEx and UPS to be bellwethers of the global economy, since they deal with such basic indicators of company health as orders and product shipments. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/UPS-1Q-profit-plunges-more-apf-15012558.html This after competitor DHL closed down opperations in North America.

content: But, but, but the banks are all showing profits.. quote: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians. Another day, another attempt by a Wall Street bank to pull a bunny out of the hat, showing off an earnings report that it hopes will elicit oohs and aahs from the market. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and, on Monday, Bank of America all tried to wow their audiences with what appeared to be — presto! — better-than-expected numbers. But in each case, investors spotted the attempts at sleight of hand, and didn’t buy it for a second. With Goldman Sachs, the disappearing month of December didn’t quite disappear (it changed its reporting calendar, effectively erasing the impact of a $1.5 billion loss that month); JPMorgan Chase reported a dazzling profit partly because the price of its bonds dropped (theoretically, they could retire them and buy them back at a cheaper price; that’s sort of like saying you’re richer because the value of your home has dropped); Citigroup pulled the same trick. Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3

content: Here is an article from Global Research that is quite interesting. I do not agree with all points, but I do agree with about 95% of what is contained herein. The rise in the equities market is indeed a stock market bubble induced by the Federal Reserve. This is easily seen when comparing the values of stocks over the past rally to the conditions of the economy. Also, the market is not the root of the problem, so it doesn't even reflect the economy as a whole. The root of the problem was that the Federal Reserve lowered the discount window to 1% six years ago, which allowed the banks to borrow the almost free money and lend it to whoever the hell they wanted to. Thus creating the housing bubble. When that burst, it created a downward spiral that caused a crash in housing, a failed banking system, failing industries and skyrocketing unemployment. Notice, the equities market itself has nothing to do with any of this. Today, the rise in the market is the result of speculators taking advantage of the Fed's capital injections before those capital injections fail. In other words, the money hungries are making their money while they can. Wells Fargo was a story of optimism over the past few weeks. But, what is really going on here. As many of you know, I was quick to show the problems associated with the FASB easing mark-to-market rules. Because, Wells Fargos profits are nothing more than their overvaluing of their worthless mortgage-backed assets, merger accounting and mortgage default moratoriums. Their profits are not a reflection of trends in the economy. A good indicator of this is the fact that their stock has been downgraded to "underperform". Deflation is still strong as ever. Fuel, food wholesale and housing prices are still falling. Unemployment is still seeing record lows as we lose 650,000 jobs a month. Both the manufacturing and Industrial sectors are at record lows. These are the true indicators of the state of the economy, not the stock market. This is a point that I have some reservations about, but that is only because I opposed the stimulus in the first place. But, it is quite interesting. Our size of our economy is about $14 trillion. The stimulus was only $787 billion. With unemployment continuing to rise, the manufacturing and industrial sectors continuing to fall, how can we expect the stimulus to have any effect on an economy where consumer spending accounts for 72% of total GDP? We can't. The only indicator of any optimism in our economy coming back is that the stock market has been rallying. And, as can be easily seen, that is not a real indicator at all. Plus, it is even scarier when you find out that the Federal Reserve is using cheap money to boost the equities market and to induce borrowing when that is exactly what got us into this mess in the first place. Here is the article: ---http://www.globalresearch.ca/index.php?context=va&aid=13236

content: And here I thought the stimulus (aka the infrastructure bailout) was supposed to help get thigns moving again. Caterpillar was supposed to be one of the main benefitiaries. Apparently, its not happening fast enough or big enough.. quote: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Caterpillar Inc., the world's largest maker of construction and mining equipment, on Tuesday reported a first-quarter loss of $112 million, hurt by sharp sales declines across the globe and a big charge for recent layoffs. The loss was Caterpillar's first since 1992 and highlighted the depth and breadth of a global downturn that forced double-digit sales drops in most of Caterpillar's product lines. Caterpillar's vast geographic reach and array of products -- including machines used to build roads and bridges, engines that power oceangoing freighters and mining trucks that haul materials like iron ore -- make it a bellwether of the world economy. The company also said the economic climate has deteriorated, despite government stimulus plans and better-than-expected commodity prices. With lending still tight and the U.S. recession tougher than expected in the first quarter, Caterpillar lowered its outlook. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/Caterpillar-posts-loss-hurt-apf-14985051.html

content: quote: Originally posted by john2x: You want a crystal ball on the economy watch companies like these: quote: ATLANTA (AP) -- UPS Inc.'s first-quarter profit plunged as fewer people sent packages and used premium services like next-day air amid the global financial crisis. The world's largest shipping carrier also gave a disappointing second-quarter outlook on Thursday, and disclosed it shed 10,000 domestic jobs during the first three months of the year. UPS earnings in the January-March period fell more than 55 percent to $401 million as revenue dropped more than 13 percent, compared to profit of $906 million a year ago. The results missed Wall Street expectations, and UPS provided an outlook for second-quarter earnings that was below analysts expectations. UPS shares fell. [...] Rival FedEx Corp. also has been facing financial headwinds from the weak economy. In March, the Memphis, Tenn.-based company said it would cut more jobs and trim wages again, after reporting its fiscal third-quarter profit tumbled 75 percent on sliding revenue. Earlier this month, FedEx said it would permanently remove 14 jets from service as part of an overall plan to reduce capacity. Economists and analysts consider FedEx and UPS to be bellwethers of the global economy, since they deal with such basic indicators of company health as orders and product shipments. -http://finance.yahoo.com/news/UPS-1Q-profit-plunges-more-apf-15012558.html This after competitor DHL closed down opperations in North America.

content: But, but, but the banks are all showing profits.. quote: This is starting to feel like amateur hour for aspiring magicians. Another day, another attempt by a Wall Street bank to pull a bunny out of the hat, showing off an earnings report that it hopes will elicit oohs and aahs from the market. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and, on Monday, Bank of America all tried to wow their audiences with what appeared to be — presto! — better-than-expected numbers. But in each case, investors spotted the attempts at sleight of hand, and didn’t buy it for a second. With Goldman Sachs, the disappearing month of December didn’t quite disappear (it changed its reporting calendar, effectively erasing the impact of a $1.5 billion loss that month); JPMorgan Chase reported a dazzling profit partly because the price of its bonds dropped (theoretically, they could retire them and buy them back at a cheaper price; that’s sort of like saying you’re richer because the value of your home has dropped); Citigroup pulled the same trick. Bank of America sold its shares in China Construction Bank to book a big one-time profit, but Ken Lewis heralded the results as “a testament to the value and breadth of the franchise.” Sydney Finkelstein, the Steven Roth professor of management at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College, also pointed out that Bank of America booked a $2.2 billion gain by increasing the value of Merrill Lynch’s assets it acquired last quarter to prices that were higher than Merrill kept them. “Although perfectly legal, this move is also perfectly delusional, because some day soon these assets will be written down to their fair value, and it won’t be pretty,” he said. Investors reacted by throwing tomatoes. Bank of America’s stock plunged 24 percent, as did other bank stocks. They’ve had enough. -http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/21/business/21sorkin.html?_r=3
